Award.AwardTitle: Future Tech Stars NSF S-STEM Scholarship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the Lake Washington Institute of Technology (LWTech) will be to develop the Future Tech Stars NSF S-STEM Scholarship Program (Future Tech Stars) to provide approximately 100 scholarships to full-time, low income, non-traditional students in four STEM disciplines: Computer Security, Information Technology Applications, Digital Gaming, and Multimedia Design. With more students attending full time, the college anticipates increased student retention, improved completion rates of degrees and certificates, and additional students transferring to a four-year university. These outcomes directly support national policy goals to improve post-high school education attainment. Future Tech Stars will address the growing need for a skilled workforce to support the vibrant technology industry in the Greater Puget Sound region and as a result will lead to economic development for the Greater Puget Sound region and improved employment outcomes for students.

The three goals of the program will be to: support student retention to complete certificates within two years and associate's degrees within three years; increase the number of students receiving a Certificate or Associate's degree in an information technology, digital media, or computer networking technology program; and increase the number of students who transfer to a four-year college or university. To support full-time students and to encourage the transition to full-time status, scholarship recipients will receive support from the program coordinator and from faculty who will provide dedicated support through writing workshops and advising. Through this work, this program will increase the body of knowledge around support services in scholarship programs, especially in programs targeting non-traditional students in technology programs. In terms of the broader impacts, the college will work closely with students and financial aid professionals to help them stay focused in studies. The students will be tracked with an Academic Early Warning system to identify problems early on and seek to help the students take corrective action. The project will involve the whole campus, including the president, the PI, and individual students. Through an evaluation of the project, the program coordinators will provide information that can be used when disseminating the results of the project. As a member of the State Board for Community and Technical Colleges (SBCTC), LWTech will access SBCTC resources for use in dissemination of results at regional conferences, through their yearly fact book, and at quarterly statewide meetings of college staff associated with divisions such as Financial Aid, Institutional Research, and Instruction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lake Washington Institute of Technology (LWTech) launched the Future Tech Stars NSF S-STEM Scholarship Program (Future Tech Stars) in 2015 and provided 100 scholarships to full-time, low-income students in four STEM disciplines: Computer Security & Network Technology, Information Technology Applications (now called Computing & Software Development), Digital Gaming, and Design.

To support full-time students and to encourage the transition to full-time status, scholarship recipients received support from the program coordinator and from faculty who provided dedicated support through writing workshops and advising. The program coordinator ensured a diverse pool of applicants and coordinated industry-specific events such as job fairs and outreach events.

The project goals included:

1) In alignment with national policy and on-campus goals, support student retention to complete program certificates within 2 years and associate?s degrees within 3 years.

The project met this goal for initial cohorts, with 66.7% of the entering fall 2016 scholarship recipients completing a degree or certificate as compared to 20.2% of students in eligible programs. (Out of all degree-seeking students entering LWTech in this cohort, 42.3% earned an award.)

2) Increase the number of students receiving a program certificate or associate?s degree in Computing & Software Development, Design, Digital Gaming, and Computer Security & Network Technology by 50% each year, with the final goal of scholarship recipients nearing the overall college completion rate of 33%.

The project met this 50% increase between years one and two of Future Tech Stars and early cohorts of students surpassed the overall college completion rate.

3) Increase the number of students who transfer to a 4-year college or university by 5% each year.

As a workforce college, transfer was not historically a focus at LWTech; however, this project served as a catalyst to begin tracking transfer rates of students using the National Student Clearinghouse. In Year 3 of work, the project team began tracking transfer rates. The largest transfer partners include the college?s new applied baccalaureate program in computer science and University of Washington.

Alongside the new applied baccalaureate program in computer science, LWTech also created a college launched a new transfer degree in computer science as well. Though not a direct result of funding from NSF, this new pathway will likely serve many internal transfer students.

Beyond individual student outcomes, this project supported the ever-expanding computer industry in the Greater Seattle area by providing students with an opportunity to work on a real-world, problem-based learning scenario to install a network server and associated software to track its temperature. This type of opportunity helps create graduates who offer strong communication skills and the ability to collaborate across disciplines. This type of skill is in-demand in the high-tech sector and, in reviewing LinkedIn data of scholarship recipients, 65% are employed in the tech sector.


Last Modified: 10/29/2019
Modified by: Alexandra Vaschillo
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Lake Washington Institute of Technology (LWTech) launched the Future Tech Stars NSF S-STEM Scholarship Program (Future Tech Stars) in 2015 and provided 100 scholarships to full-time, low-income students in four STEM disciplines: Computer Security & Network Technology, Information Technology Applications (now called Computing & Software Development), Digital Gaming, and Design. To support full-time students and to encourage the transition to full-time status, scholarship recipients received support from the program coordinator and from faculty who provided dedicated support through writing workshops and advising. The program coordinator ensured a diverse pool of applicants and coordinated industry-specific events such as job fairs and outreach events. The project goals included: 1) In alignment with national policy and on-campus goals, support student retention to complete program certificates within 2 years and associate?s degrees within 3 years. The project met this goal for initial cohorts, with 66.7% of the entering fall 2016 scholarship recipients completing a degree or certificate as compared to 20.2% of students in eligible programs. (Out of all degree-seeking students entering LWTech in this cohort, 42.3% earned an award.) 2) Increase the number of students receiving a program certificate or associate?s degree in Computing & Software Development, Design, Digital Gaming, and Computer Security & Network Technology by 50% each year, with the final goal of scholarship recipients nearing the overall college completion rate of 33%. The project met this 50% increase between years one and two of Future Tech Stars and early cohorts of students surpassed the overall college completion rate. 3) Increase the number of students who transfer to a 4-year college or university by 5% each year. As a workforce college, transfer was not historically a focus at LWTech; however, this project served as a catalyst to begin tracking transfer rates of students using the National Student Clearinghouse. In Year 3 of work, the project team began tracking transfer rates. The largest transfer partners include the college?s new applied baccalaureate program in computer science and University of Washington. Alongside the new applied baccalaureate program in computer science, LWTech also created a college launched a new transfer degree in computer science as well. Though not a direct result of funding from NSF, this new pathway will likely serve many internal transfer students. Beyond individual student outcomes, this project supported the ever-expanding computer industry in the Greater Seattle area by providing students with an opportunity to work on a real-world, problem-based learning scenario to install a network server and associated software to track its temperature. This type of opportunity helps create graduates who offer strong communication skills and the ability to collaborate across disciplines. This type of skill is in-demand in the high-tech sector and, in reviewing LinkedIn data of scholarship recipients, 65% are employed in the tech sector.
